keyTakeAways: The Nobel Prizes are among the world’s most prestigious awards, established by Alfred Nobel’s will in 1895, recognizing individuals who have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.

The prizes are awarded by five institutions: the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences (physics, chemistry, economics), the Nobel Assembly at Karolinska Institutet (medicine), the Swedish Academy (literature), and the Norwegian Nobel Committee (peace).
Each laureate receives a gold medal, diploma, and a cash award of 11 million Swedish kronor ($1.2 million).
The nomination process is confidential and strictly regulated, with nominees selected by experts, academics, and past winners, and decisions kept secret for 50 years.
The science prizes emphasize long-term impact and scientific validity, while the peace prize often responds to current global events and human rights issues.

The 2024 winners include Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun (medicine), John Hopfield and Geoffrey Hinton (physics), David Baker, Demis Hassabis, and John Jumper (chemistry), Han Kang (literature), and Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James Robinson (economics).

This year’s nominees include controversies involving U.S. President Donald Trump, who has claimed he deserves the peace prize for ending wars, though experts believe his chances are slim due to the committee’s focus on durable peace and institutional efforts.

The Trump administration’s political interference has raised concerns about academic freedom, with statements from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences warning of long-term democratic and scientific consequences.

The 2025 medicine prize was awarded to Mary Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell, and Shimon Sakaguchi for their discoveries concerning peripheral immune tolerance, which have led to new treatments for cancer and autoimmune diseases.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The 2025 Nobel Prizes have officially begun with the announcement of the medicine prize to Mary Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell, and Shimon Sakaguchi for their discoveries in peripheral immune tolerance, which have advanced treatments for cancer and autoimmune diseases. The full announcement schedule spans from October 6 to October 13, covering medicine, physics, chemistry, literature, peace, and economics. The prizes, established by Alfred Nobel’s will, are awarded by specialized institutions and represent the world’s highest recognition of scientific, literary, and humanitarian achievements. While the science prizes emphasize long-term impact and discovery, the peace prize remains responsive to global conflicts and political narratives. This year, controversy arises from U.S. President Donald Trump’s claims of deserving the peace prize, with experts noting the committee’s focus on durable peace and institutional efforts, not individual self-promotion. Concerns have also been raised about political interference in science, particularly from the Trump administration, which threatens academic freedom. The article highlights both the scientific breakthroughs and the political dimensions of the Nobel Prizes, underscoring their global significance and the balance between scientific merit and public discourse.
